awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Integrating Costs of Investment in Parental Care from Telomeres to Hormones
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals can benefit by having many offspring that survive and reproduce. To increase offspring survival, parents may provide extensive parental care and exhibit aggression towards predators or intruders. However, raising and defending a large family can increase stress on parents. Additionally, hormones often regulate expression of behaviors. For example, testosterone is associated with reduced parental care and increased aggression in many birds. High levels of testosterone have been linked to reduced survival in birds, but the mechanisms underlying this link are unknown. One hypothesis is that testosterone shortens telomeres. Telomeres are short sequences of DNA that protect the ends of chromosomes and can affect survival. Stress can also shorten telomere lengths, and shorter telomeres have been associated with reduced lifespan. The researchers have manipulated brood sizes of eastern bluebirds to alter parental care, aggression, and stress, which can all interact with testosterone levels. They will determine how family size, behavior, and hormones affect telomere lengths to impact longevity and survival. The researchers will also develop education programs for local high school students to learn fundamental concepts in the fields of behavioral ecology and physiology.

The researchers have found that bluebirds have considerable individual variation in testosterone production. Testosterone is implicated in important, fitness-related behaviors. The costs of elevating testosterone are also well-documented. Although much has been done to elucidate relationships between behaviors and the hormonal mechanisms that regulate them, there is currently very little information about how behavioral and physiological links might be tied to mechanisms that affect survival (i.e., telomere lengths and telomere loss). The researchers will analyze previously collected blood samples to measure testosterone, corticosterone, and telomere lengths. They will relate these physiological measurements to previously recorded behavioral data. By linking costly behaviors mediated by testosterone to telomere lengths, this study will take an integrative approach to answering questions that span the fields of behavioral ecology, endocrinology, and evolution. Data will archived at Oklahoma State University and requests for data will be fulfilled upon approval of the researchers.

por.por_cntn:
While producing a large brood of offspring can be a benefit for animals, the work that goes into raising those offspring can be immensely stressful for the parents. Being raised in a large brood might also be equally stressful for the offspring. Stress is known to shorten telomeres, short, repeated segments of DNA that influence survival; shorter telomeres are associated with reduced survival. High levels of testosterone are also associated with reduced survival, but it is unclear why this pattern occurs. One explanation is that testosterone shortens telomeres. In many species of birds, testosterone also regulates parental care and aggressive behaviors, like protecting the offspring. High levels of testosterone are associated with increased aggression, but reduced parental care. The goals of this project were 1) to understand the relationships among testosterone levels, parental and nest defense behavior, and telomere lengths, and 2) to determine how brood size impacts signatures of stress in adults and offspring. We used a wild population of eastern bluebirds (Sialia sialis) as our study system.

Unlike some other studies on songbirds, testosterone levels were not related to parental or aggressive nest defense behavior in response to a nest competitor for male and female bluebirds. This finding confirms previous patterns observed in our population, and suggests that testosterone may not regulate parental and aggressive behaviors in this species. Individual male and female bluebirds were consistent across parental and nest defense contexts in their ability to secrete testosterone. Relatively few studies have sampled hormones at multiple time points, but it is important to do so to gain a robust understanding of consistent individual variation in hormonal profiles.

When we investigated the effects of enlarging or reducing brood sizes, we found that adults raising enlarged broods visited the nest more overall than adults raising reduced broods. Telomere lengths were not related to adult behavior, testosterone levels, or stress hormone levels. None of these physiological measurements were impacted by the brood size manipulation. It is possible that resources, such as food, were abundant, allowing adults to adjust their behavior in relation to brood size without suffering some of the costs.

Because adult bluebirds adjusted their behavior in response to the brood size manipulation, the nestlings did not incur many costs, at least in terms of what we measured. Growth rates, stress hormone levels, telomere lengths, and the rate of telomere shortening did not differ across enlarged, reduced, and control broods. The brood size manipulation affected feather coloration such that female nestlings raised in enlarged broods had significantly less colorful rump feathers, but more colorful chest feathers than female nestlings raised in reduced broods. While we measured adult feeding rates, we did not measure size or quality of food provided to offspring. It is possible that nestlings in the different treatment groups received different quality food.

Surprisingly, male nestlings had longer telomeres and slower rates of telomere loss before leaving the nest than female nestlings. Female nestlings may have been more sensitive to stressors in their early-life environment than males were.

Funding from this award allowed co-PI Ambardar to travel to North Dakota State University to learn techniques for measuring telomere lengths from collaborator, Dr. Britt Heidinger. The co-PI traveled to the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology in Portland, OR in 2016 to present her research to other scientists. Thanks to this award, she was also able to finish analyzing hormone samples from adult and nestling bluebirds. A portion of the research has been published, with three additional manuscripts from the work in preparation. During the course of the project, co-PI Ambardar supervised 20 field volunteers who assisted with data collection, and mentored seven undergraduate researchers, six of whom are women. Two of these students will be coauthors on one of the publications resulting from this research. She engaged in several science outreach activities to enhance scientific understanding among the general public. These activities included giving presentations on citizen science and backyard birds at the Oklahoma Wildlife Expo, an event attended by over 40,000 people of all ages from across Oklahoma, and co-presenting a workshop on science communication, which was presented to zoology and natural resources graduate students and the Society of Women Engineers at Oklahoma State University.
